head.title: Saddle Up, Cowboy, This Here's Queens

hedline.hl1: Saddle Up, Cowboy, This Here's Queens

abstract.p: Debra Singleton opens Debbie's Reins and Things, which offers supplies and equine equipment for people who stable and ride horses in Howard Beach, Queens, NYC; photo (S)

block.p: Grazing Horses. Rolling green pastures. The Wild West? Nope, Queens.
Around Howard Beach, there are seven horse stables and a year-old tack shop; the only one in the area, where a wall banner says, ''This is Horse Country.''
Grazing Horses. Rolling green pastures. The Wild West? Nope, Queens.
Around Howard Beach, there are seven horse stables and a year-old tack shop; the only one in the area, where a wall banner says, ''This is Horse Country.''

At 83-11 South Conduit Avenue, in a red steel shack on the premises of the Cedar Lane Stable, Debbie's Reins and Things supplies riders with equine equipment, from reins ($25 to $75) and harnesses ($15 to $100) to belt buckles ($20 to $50) and riding helmets ($55).
''Since we had all the horses here and we had the need for it,'' said Debra Singleton, the shop's owner, ''why not?''
Ms. Singleton (above), began riding at 13 and has a 25-year-old Belgian quarter horse,Justice. She said the closest fully stocked riding supply shop is half an hour away in Elmont on Long Island.

''If we need something for the horse immediately, like Band-Aids or ointment, she has it there,'' said Jesse Ellis, assistant vice president at the Federation of Black Cowboys, the organization that owns and operates the stables.

Ms. Singleton, also a full-time administrative specialist at Bell Atlantic, runs the shop with the help of her mother, Betty Johnson. In April, they were awarded a loan from the Regional Economic Development Assistance Corporation, a program that aids start-up businesses. With the loan, $15,000 over two and a half years, Ms. Singleton has been able to renovate the store and put up a Web site at www.debbiesreinsandthings.com.
